titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Sarah Orne Jewett letters, 1877 June 15-circa 1890s RL.11414
titlestmt.author: Megan E. Lewis

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-02-16 12:13:51 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Sarah Orne Jewett letters consist of two pieces of correspondence written by the author to an editor, Mr. Sawyer, and to Lucy Coffin. Sarah Orne Jewett was a well-known 19th century author whose fiction is set in her native rural Maine. In the first letter, Jewett declines to send Mr. Sawyer anything to print in the first issue of his magazine, as she has been ill and busy, and doesn't want to write something in a hurry, although she wishes him well with his new publication. The second is a condolence letter to Lucy Coffin of Newbury, Massachusetts on the loss of her father. The Coffins were a prominent Massachusetts family.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Sarah Orne Jewett was a 19th century American writer who published novels, short stories, and poetry. Her writing chronicled life in her native rural Maine and featured strong female characters. Beginning in 1881, Jewett lived with her friend and companion Annie Adams Fields, the widow of James Thomas Fields, who had been the editor of the Atlantic Monthly. Jewett's best-known work is her short story collection "The Country of the Pointed Firs," (1896) which has been cited as an influence on Elizabeth Strout's Pulizer prize-winning "Olive Kitteridge."

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Sarah Orne Jewett letters were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2015.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Sarah Orne Jewett letters, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Megan E. Lewis, March, 2017
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2015-0050-LUBMSS267-268

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of two autograph manuscript letters written by Sarah Orne Jewett. The first is addressed to a Mr. Sawyer, the editor of a new journal, declining to send him anything to print in his first issue, as she has been ill and doesn't wish to write something in a hurry. She sends him "hearty good wishes for the success of his magazine," asks him to send her a prospectus, and "suppose[s] that, like all editors, you have more verses than you wish to print." The letter is on a single sheet of folded paper with writing on three pages dated 1877 June 15 and written from South Berwick, [Maine]. The second letter is a sympathy note written on mourning stationery and addressed to Miss [Lucy] Coffin dated 26 December, but lacking a year. A Boston address appears at the top. Jewett expresses sympathy for the loss of Miss Coffin's father from both her and her companion Mrs. Field, and reminisces about a day they had spent together in Newburyport. Jewett references John Greenleaf Whittier, who was a student of Lucy's cousin Joseph while at Dartmouth College. The Coffin Family was prominent in New England and lived in Newbury, Massachusetts for many generations.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Sarah Orne Jewett papers at Bowdoin College Library: Viewed March 24, 2017

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Transcripts of selected Jewett letters, including the two letters in this collection, are availalbe at: http://www.sarahornejewett.org/soj/let/Corresp/1877.html
